person.note: This transliteration fits no known form, but obviously this is the name intended.
The Greek name is followed by the Hebrew שלום, see Introduction 6.2.2.
So is this name recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 58, and Introduction 2.2.1.

The editor wrote that the names on this papyri “all … appear to be Jewish,” but since we are dealing with the sixth century, they could of course also all be Christian, see Introduction 6.6.7. The papyrus is signed with a cross.
The papyrus is composed in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.4.
The interpretation of this name as the biblical אסתר is suggested by the editor.
Apeitheon’s daughter writes to her father and greets this woman in the letter. She is probably not her mother, but could be her father’s wife.
Jewishness suggested based on name, but see above, n. 1, and she could be Christian, see Introduction 6.6.7.
This transliteration fits no known form, but obviously this is the name intended.
Found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3. It is accompanied by a menorah (see Introduction 6.3.1) and the Hebrew word – שאלום (see Introduction 6.2.2).
Jewishness indicated by a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1, the Hebrew word Amen, written in Greek (άμν), see Introduction 6.2.5, and the Hebrew word – שלום, see Introduction 6.2.2.
In Greek – παρθένος̔σία ἐτῶν εἴκοσει δύω .

CIJ thought the inscription Jewish because of the name – Esther – and the phrase – ̓σία (pious). The first could also be Christian, see Introduction 6.6.7, but the second is uniquely Jewish, see Rutgers, Jews in Late Ancient Rome, 194.
Josephus records the name of the queen as ̓Εσθήρα (e.g. AJ11:199), see Introduction 2.2.1.
Jewishness suggested based on the name (and on the name Jacob also found on the inscription), but this would also require an earlier date for the inscription, see Introduction 6.6.7.
The editor dated the epitaph to the Byzantine period.
For the loss of the א at the head of the name see vol. 1, Introduction 2.5.5, p. 29.
The amulet is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.2.
The amulet is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
The form could be variation on the same name, or the ו could be a scribal error, see Introduction 2.8.1.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of mostly biblical names, so I consider them all Jewish.
The male ברכה is transliterated in the Vulgate as Baracha, see Introduction 2.2.2.

This inscription was considered Jewish because of this name, but see Introduction 6.6.2, and above, n. 1. The inscription also includes the pagan formula D(is) M(anibus) (to the gods of the underworld), see Introduction 6.10.2.1.
Appears in rabbinic literature and rabbis come to stay at her guest establishment, see Introduction 6.7. She also has a biblical name see Introduction 6.6.
This figure is obviously fictitious, as is the entire episode. The name דבורה, like most biblical women’s names, was not used during the Second Temple period.
She is a contemporary of Judah (35) (B/M) in vol. 1, p. 113.
So is the name recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 51, and Introduction 2.2.1.
Jewishness suggested based on name, see Introduction 6.6.

Since the papyrus displays no particular pagan or Christian elements, and since it shows many Jewish ones (mention of the archangels and King David, see Introduction 6.9.1), Goodenough, Jewish Symbols 2, 166-8, claimed this person could be Jewish. This, however, is not very likely because of the almost complete absence of Jews from Coptic texts.
The papyrus is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
So is this name recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 17, and Introduction 2.2.1.
Found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3.
See above, n. 5. On the single instead of double ν see Introduction 2.2.1.1.3.
See above, n. 6. It is accompanied by the Hebrew word Shalom in Greek (σάλωμ), see Introduction 6.2.5.
See below, n. 12. The declension is probably influenced by the Greek, see Introduction 2.4.2.2.1.
See above, n. 6. It is accompanied by three menorot, see Introduction 6.3.1.
The inscription is bilingual. So in Latin. The Hebrew has חנה. This is the form of this name in the Vulgate, see Introduction 2.2.2.
In Latin – etate LIV. In Hebrew – בת נ' ו' שנה.
The inscription is bilingual (Hebrew and Latin), see Introduction 6.2.3.
The Hebrew in the inscription is in verse, indicating a later date. Also, the inscription was found in a locality of a medieval Jewish cemetery, see also Introduction 6.5.8.
Jewishness indicated by a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1.
This is the reading of Clermont-Ganneau, see above, n. 5. CIJ read ̓Αραβάννας.
The inscription was considered Jewish because of the names, but they could also be Christian, as are the symbols on the inscription, see Introduction 6.6.7.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.

state.note: Asyncrite (1), Marcus (18) Aurelius (39) Jacob (63) Eutychius (2)’s wife

person.note: This burial inscription includes biblical names, see Introduction 6.6.1.It also mentions a synagogue, but this is not a good indication of Jewishness in Greece, see 6.4.1.2.2.4.
Greek inscription is followed by the Hebrew משכב (=resting place), see Introduction 6.2.2.
Jewishness indicated by son’s name, see Introduction 6.6.8.
Jewishness suggested based on the name, but see above, n. 1.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of mostly biblical names, so I consider them all Jewish.
This transliteration fits no known form, but obviously this is the name intended.
Jewishness indicated by name, see Introduction 6.6.
The form is already recorded under Joanna (3) (S-H/F) in vol. 1, pp. 420-1.
In Latin “ex Iudaea ad Christianam religionem conuersa est,” (having converted from the Jewish to the Christian religion), see Introduction 6.1.6.3.
On this form see under Joanna (1) (S-H/F) in vol. 1, p. 420-1.
Jewishness indicated by name, see Introduction 6.6.
The papyrus is dated to one of these years.
See Introduction 2.1, and above, n. 5. On the interchange of ω and ο see Introduction 2.2.1.1.3. On the alternative suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2.1.
So is the prophet’s name recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 93, and Introduction 2.2.1.
Jewishness is indicated by her brother-in-law’s membership in the Jewish politeuma, see Introduction 6.4.2.1.
So is this name recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 74 and Introduction 2.2.1.

In Greek – Προστάτης. On her being a woman see B. Brooten, “The Gender of Ιαηλ in the Jewish Inscription from Aphrodisias,” in H. W. Atteridge, J. J. Collins and T. H. Tobin (eds.), Of Scribes and Scrolls: Studies on the Hebrew Bible, Intertestamental Judaism and Christian Origins Presented to John Strugnell (New York 1990) 163-7.
On the Aphrodisias inscription see Introduction 6.1.6.1.1.
Jewishness indicated by name, see Introduction 6.6.

state.note: Appidia (1), Lucius (4) Domitius (2) Abba (4)’s wife, Domitia (2) Felicita (1)’s mother

person.note: This transliteration fits no known form, but obviously this is the name intended.
Found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3.
This is CIJ’s reading. JIWE 1, 122, read לצד[יק].
Jewishness decided by Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.3.
The inscription is probably late, see Introduction 6.5.8.

Although this form appears once in LXX for Miriam (Num 12:1 – H & R Suppl. 108), it is probably a feminine form of the Latin name Marius, see N. Cohen, “The Greek and Latin Transcriptions Mariam and Maria: Their Sociological Significance,” Lĕšonénu38 (1974) 170-80 (Hebrew). In this corpus, women who bear this form of name are only considered Jewish if other criteria apply, and see Introduction 1.2.4.
Jewishness suggested based on name, but see Introduction 6.6.4. None of Paul’s helpers in Romans are described ethnically or religiously.
These are Paul’s dates, see vol. 1, Introduction 7.1, p. 51.
On this woman see Ilan, Silencing the Queen, 27-30.

She is mentioned often in writings of ancient alchemists, mainly Zosimos of Panopolis, but only here is she described as (almost) specifically Jewish – καὶ Μαρίας τὴν καμινογραφίαν καὶ ἂλλους ̓Ιουδαίους (and Maria the writer on ovens and other Jews). From various studies written about her, it is not obvious how difficult it is to confirm her Jewish identity, perhaps because in later generation this was undisputed “common knowledge,” see e.g. R. Patai, “Maria the Jewess: Founding Mother of Alchemy,” Ambix 29 (1982) 177-97. See also the note in M. P. E. Berthelot, Les Origenes de l’alchemie(Paris 1885) 56, and the identical quote of this text in Patai, ibid., 196, n. 63. Berthelot mentions a number of manuscripts but does not explain what they are, and does not transcribe them precisely. Thus, we only have his French translation of these texts, and Patai’s English text rendered from these, in which Maria is reputed to have said: “you are not of our race, you are not of the race of Abraham.” She is probably to be identified with Μαρία τις ̔Εβραία σοφή (Maria, a Hebrew sage – on this title see Harvey, ‘Good Jews’) mentioned by Syncellus, Chronographia, 471, because she is said to be initiated into the secrets of gold and silver. Syncellus identified her teacher, Democritus, with the pre-Socratic philosopher, and dated her to the Persian period, placing her in Memphis, Egypt, but the tradition that identifies the founder of alchemy with Democritus is clearly pseudoepigraphic, and this date is far too early, see N. Janowitz, Magic in the Roman World: Pagans, Jews and Christians (New York 2001) 59-69.
Syncellus, Chronographia, 471, places her in Μέμφεως, namely Egyptian Memphis.
This is the accepted date of Zosimos of Panopolis, in whose writings she is first mentioned.
See below, n. 23. The declension is Greek, but not the standard one recorded by Josephus.
Paid the Jewish tax, see Introduction 6.1.5.
Jewishness suggested based on name, but see Introduction 6.6.4.
So is this name recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 108, and Introduction 2.2.1.
Jewishness suggested based on name and orthography, see above, n. 1.
The reading is according to Clarysse, “Jews in Trikomia,” 192. The editio princeps has Γαρίμμις. See below, n. 29. The declension is Greek, but not the standard one recorded by Josephus.
See above, n. 24, but see also previous note.
Josephus transliterates the name as Μαριάμη, see e.g. BJ1:241. On the double consonant see Introduction 2.3.3.4.
Jewishness indicated by father’s name, see Introduction 6.6.9.1. See above, n. 24.
These are the dates in which the scribe wrote these papyri, see PC 4, p. 18.
Jewishness indicated by all the biblical names mentioned in this family, particularly Judah, see Introduction 6.6.8.
It has been suggested by Fikhman, SCI 15 (1996) 226, that this papyrus is associated with Jews. I assume he means those with biblical names, but see Introduction 6.6.7.
These are the dates of the emperor Heraclius mentioned in the papyrus.
The papyrus is composed in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.4.
Jewishness suggested based on the titles of her son and husband, “archon,” but see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.3. Also her name may be Jewish, but see Introduction 6.6.4.
See Introduction 2.1, and above, n. 2. The declension is probably a scribal error, see Introduction 2.8.5.
Found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3.
So is this name recorded in the Vulgate, see Introduction 2.2.2.
CIJ thought the woman was Jewish because of her name, but this is not a typically biblical name, see JIWE2, 629(i), and Introduction 6.6.4.
See above, n. 41. The inscription is accompanied by a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1.
Jewishness suggested based on title, γερουσιάρχου in the inscription, but see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.3.
The only indication that she is Jewish is her name, and it was not exclusively Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.4.

state.note: Political petition, Graffito, Pompeii, Della Corte

person.note: See above, n. 46. The declension is probably influenced by the Greek, see Introduction 2.4.2.2.2.
In Latin – mortua est ann LX (CIJ 616).
See above, n. 41. One of them is accompanied by three menorot, see Introduction 6.3.1.
In Latin – qua bixit annis XXV.
Jewishness was suggested based on the names Judah and Mariam together, and see Introduction 6.6.8,but the inscription has pagan characteristics, see Introduction 6.6.5.
The inscription is trilingual. So in the Hebrew. Reading according to JIWE1, 183. CIJread – מרים. The transliteration is probably from the Greek/Latin, see Introduction 2.3.2.1.
The inscription is trilingual. So in the Latin, see above, n. 66.
The inscription is trilingual. So in the Latin and Greek. This form is recorded under Mara (3) (S-H/F) in vol. 1, p. 422.
In Latin and Hebrew – Quira; קירא.
The inscription is trilingual (Hebrew, Greek and Latin), see Introduction 6.2.2, and is accompanied by a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1.
In Latin – quae vixit annis XVIII.

The woman is described on her epitaph as “Judeae” (Jewess), see Introduction 6.1.1.5.The inscription also includes the pagan formula D(is) M(anibus) (to the gods of the underworld), but, see Introduction 6.10.2.1, and Kraemer, HTR 82 (1989) 41-2.
See above, n. 2. On the interchange of ι and ε see Introduction 2.3.3.2.

Jewishness was suggested by the formula ̓Εά[ν] τις ἀνύξῃ τὸν τάφον δώσει τῇ ἁγιωτά [τῃ] συναγω[γη͂] ἀρ(γύρου) λ(ίτραν μίαν ) (If anyone opens the tomb, he will pay to the most holy synagogue [one] pound silver). However, this inscription comes from Greece, see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.4.
Jewishness indicated by husband’s name, see Introduction 6.6.9.1. On inscriptions from Larissa see Introduction 6.5.6.

Jewishness suggested based on name, but see Introduction 6.6.4. The inscription also mentions a Gerusia (council of elders) but this was not a uniquely Jewish institution, see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.3. The fact that it does not state that the deceased is Jewish makes it more suspect in light of other sarcophagi from Hierapolis, see Introduction 6.1.1.3. IJO 2 did not include it in its corpus, see p. 399, n. 161.
The inscription was found on a Jewish ossuary from Jerusalem, see Introduction 6.5.7.
This person is recorded under Mariam (28) (B/F) in vol. 1, p. 243, but not included in the statistics, see Introduction 6.3.1, pp. 28-9 in that volume.
This is the Hebrew transliteration of the Latin Maria, see under Mariam (26, 33, 34, 36, 41, 48, 55, 63) (B/F) in vol. 1, pp. 243-4. It was very common.

In Hebrew – הגיורת הדלסית. The initial reading of the inscription suggested that she be described as הדולקת. E. L. Sukenik “Varia Epigraphica Judaica,” in S. Assaf (ed.), Asher Gulak and S. Klein Festschrift(Jerusalem 1942) 133-4 (Hebrew), suggested reading the inscription דילסת, i.e. of the Greek island Delos.
Described on her ossuary as גירת. The inscription was found in a Jewish tomb in Jerusalem, see Introduction 6.1.6.2.
This person is recorded under Mariam (33) (B/F) in vol. 1, p. 243, but not included in the statistics, see Introduction 6.3.1, pp. 28-9 in that volume.
The final ‘m’ can be part of the Hebrew Mariam, or it could be a Latin dativ suffix, in an unconventional declension, of Maria, see above, n. 46.
In Latin – cua vixit an XXXVIII.
The editor thought she was Jewish because of the orthography of the Mariem, see above, n. 101, but see also Introduction 6.6.4, and the inscription also includes probably Christian symbols.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
This seems to be the Latin transliteration of the Greek, Μαριάμη, which is the way Josephus transliterates the biblical Miriam, see above, n. 29.
See previous note, but the inscription is pagan, including the formula D(is) M(anibus) (to the gods of the underworld), see Introduction 6.10.2.1.
Jewishness was suggested based on the names Judah and Mariam together, and see Introduction 6.6.8,but the inscription has pagan characteristics, see Introduction 6.6.5.
See above, n. 63, and on son’s title, ἄρχω[ν], but see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.3.
See above, n. 86. IJO 2, considered it non-Jewish and did not include it in its corpus, see p. 490, n. 30.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.

For the same orthography, with a single μ see above, n. 27, and Introduction 2.3.3.4. Cohen, Lĕšonénu 38 (1974) 180, n. 31, suggested reading this inscription as Μαρια Μνιις (namely memorial of Maria).
The print is not clear, it could be Μανιέμη, but the photograph published with it clearly suggests this form. This is probably another variation of the form, see above, nn. 23 and 29.
See above, n. 86. IJO 2 decided not to include the inscription, see p. 196, n. 189 decided not to include the inscription.
The editor dated the inscription to the “Kaiserzeit.”
This transliteration fits no known form, but obviously this is the name intended.
Jewishness of inscription decided by 1. a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1; and 2. the Hebrew formula – בשלום [ע]ם [צדי]קים, see Introduction 6.2.2.
So is this name recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 129, and Introduction 2.2.1.
Described in the text as ἐκ φυλῆς ̓Ισραήλ (of the tribe of Israel), see Introduction 6.1.3. She then converts to Christianity, see Introduction 6.1.6.3.
The apocryphal acts of the Apostles are fictitious composition, see vol. 1, Introduction 5.6, p. 42.
This transliteration fits no known form, but obviously this is the name intended. Why an initial ε is added is unclear.
This family is described in the text as Σαμαρῖται (Samaritans), see Introduction 6.1.6.4.
See above, n. 5. On the double/single consonant see introduction 2.3.3.4.
The vast majority of persons in this family has biblical names, which suggests a Jewish family, but this is the Christian era, and they could be Christian, see Introduction 6.6.7.
See above, n. 2. For the interchange of ε and η see Introduction 2.3.3.3. On the single consonant see Introduction 2.3.3.4.
Found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3.
In Greek – μόνβνδρο (interpreted as μόν<α>ανδρος) ἒζησα ἒτη μδ’.
See above, n. 2. On the single consonant see Introduction 2.3.3.4.
Jewishness indicated by a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1.
This is not the standard Latin transliteration of this name, but this name is clearly intended. On the transliteration of β/ב with ‘v’ see Introduction 2.4.2.2.
In Latin – quae vixit annum unum mensem unum deis XVII (=1 year, 1 month and 17 days).

It was considered Jewish because of the name, but CIJ considered this insufficient proof. The name could likewise be Christian, see Introduction 6.6.7, and the typical Christian formulae “in pace” and “deposita” make this more likely.
The inscription is dated – Flavio Caesario et Nonio Attico vv. cc. conss.
So is this name recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 129, and Introduction 2.2.1.

This papyrus is dated to the fourth century (early Christian) and is replete with biblical names. Some would interpret them as Jews (e.g. Fikhman, SCI 13 [1994] 213-4), but the editor cautiously noted “Also remarkable is the fact that this wooden board contains a certain concentration of ‘Jewish’ names … These names are probably connected with Christianization of the village of Kellis during the 4th century … as there seems no good reason to think that there was a kind of ‘Jewish quarter’ in the village or its neighborhood,” see Introduction 6.6.7.
This transliteration fits no known form, but obviously this is the name intended.
Jewishness indicated by name, see Introduction 6.6.

The inscription is in Jewish characters. It was probably not included in JIWE 1 because for paleographic reasons it was considered late, see Introduction 6.2.3. But the form of the name Joshua – ישוע – is very early, see under Joshua (31) (B/M).
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. The verso of this papyrus is a list of mostly biblical names, and all are, therefore, considered Jewish here, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
There is no standard transliteration of this name. The variations are many. For a discussion of their nature see above, n. 1.
Jewishness indicated by father’s name, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
The papyrus is dated to one of these years.
Jewishness suggested based on name, but see above, n. 1.
Jewishness based on grandfather (Jacob [6])’s name, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.

The papyrus, a list of names, includes one biblical name, but was identified by the editors as all-Jewish. I have listed all the people from the papyrus here, but as doubtful Jews, see Introduction 6.6.9.2.
Paid the Jewish tax, see Introduction 6.1.5.
So in CPJ486b, see above, n. 4.
Note that she is a sister of the previous and has the same second name.

See above, n. 8. However, she does not come from Egypt and should perhaps be treated differently. Also, changing her name from Sambathis to Athenais may suggest that the new owner found something distasteful in her name (perhaps that she was Jewish). However, this remains conjecture.
The reading is according to Clarysse, “Jews in Trikomia,” 195, see Introduction 2.1. The editio princeps had ̓Αβατέρις, and see above, n. 4.
See above, n. 8. This reading may well be incorrect, see previous note and Introduction 6.6.9.2.
Found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3. The inscription is accompanied by a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1.
Found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3.
In Greek – ἐτῶν δύο μηνῶν ἑπτα (=2 years and 7 months).
Found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3.
See above, n. 99. However, the inscription is dissimilar to any other in Monte Verde and scholars think it is an old pagan inscription reused in the Jewish catacomb, see JIWE 2, no. 618.
See above, n. 8. IJO 1, App21, considered it non-Jewish.
The editor dates the epitaph to the “Imperial” period.
This is an alternative Semitic suffix, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.6, p. 23 and 2.4.4.1, pp. 27-8.
The inscription is in Jewish characters, from Jerusalem, and found with a cluster of such inscriptions, probably incised by early pilgrims, see Introduction 6.2.2.
There are doubts about the date of the inscription. Some pronounce it later, see below, n. 124.
So the word סקליא is interpreted.
This is the opinion of most scholars. Some date the inscription later, see CIJ.
This inscription comes from the Jewish cemetery of Leontopolis, see Introduction 6.5.1, and see also Introduction 6.6.6.
In Latin – quae vix ann IIII mens VIIII d XII (=4 years, 8 months and 12 days).
See above, n. 8. The inscription also includes the pagan formula D(is) M(anibus) (to the gods of the underworld), see Introduction 6.10.2.1.
So in CIJ69*, see above, n. 4.
The inscription refers to her owner – patrono suo.
The first inscription is her epitaph. The second she erected for her patron.
See above, n. 8. CIJ rejected it because the deceased had been cremated.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.

See above, n. 8.The inscription also includes the formula D(is) M(anibus) (to the gods of the underworld), see Introduction 6.10.2.1. CIJ wrote “si réellement Clauidia Sabbathis fut juive, son Judaïsme fut singulièrement accomodant. Mariée à un esclave de l’empereur, elle se fait ensevelir sous la protection des dieux Mânes.”
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
See above, n. 8. The inscription includes the pagan formula D(is) O(mnibus) M(anibus) (to the gods of all the underworld), see Introduction 6.10.2.1.
Jewishness suggested based on the name Judah (81) found in this burial cave, see Introduction 6.6.8 and 6.5.5.
In Latin – vix anno (uno) dieb(us) (vigniti) uno.

Found in the cemetery at Gamarat, Carthage, see Introduction 6.5.4. See also above, n. 8. Also the inscription includes the pagan formula D(is) M(anibus) S(acrum) (sacred to the gods of the underworld), see Introduction 6.10.2.1.
Found on an ossuary from Jerusalem, see Introduction 6.5.7.

This burial cave was identified as housing Jews from Cyrenaica, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.3.1.1, p. 49. This person is recorded under Sabatis (1) (G/F) in vol. 1, p. 323, but not included in the statistics.
In Latin – vix anno I dieb XXI (=1 year and 21 days).
Described in the text as θρεπτή.
See above, n. 8. IJO 1 failed to notice the inscription altogether.
On this definitely being the Greek transliteration of the name שלום, see under Salome (B/F) in vol. 1, p. 251, n. 2.
She is mentioned in Galen as providing a recipe for a medicine. On this woman see Ilan, Silencing the Queen, 25-7.
Jewishness indicated by name, see above, n. 1.
Galen mentions no provenance for her but the fact that she wrote in Greek probably indicates that she resided in the Diaspora. Galen was from Pergamum in Asia. Perhaps she was too.
If she was a contemporary of Galen, this is her time.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of names, most of which are biblical, so I consider them all Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
This form was popular in Cyrenaica. Perhaps it is a North African name that has nothing to do with the Hebrew שלום.
Her father has a Semitic name and his description may be reconstructed as πατρὸς συναγωγῆς (̔Ε)βρ(αι)ων (father of the synagogue of the Hebrews), see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.2 and 6.1.2.

There are at least two illegible letters at the beginning of the inscription. CIJread this as the (otherwise unknown) male name יתשלום. JIWE 1, 25, read it the blessing יהי שלום. However, despite the added letters, I believe the most likely reading is the feminine (and well known) name שלום, see above, n. 1.
The seal is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.2.
The seal is not dated. Late antique date presumed.

This is my reading, and see its justification in Ilan, Silencing the Queen, 274. CIJand JIWE1, 179, read Salo(mo)nula. On this name sometimes recorded with n/ν/נ see under Salome (16) (B/F) in vol. 1, and n. 2, pp. 249-52.
In Latin – an I mens IIII die I (=1 year and 4 months and 1 day).
The deceased is described in the inscription as “Iudaea” (Jewess), see Introduction 6.1.1.5.

Jewishness suggested based on the formula Ο̓[δεὶς] ἀθάν[α]τος (no-one is immortal), but this is not a uniquely Jewish formula, see Introduction 6.10.3.1. It could have been based on the name (see above, n. 1) but it is clearly an editor’s reconstruction. IJO 2 rejected the Jewishness of this inscription, see p. 493, n. 8.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
Jewishness indicated by the biblical name Joshua (18) mentioned on this tombstone, see Introduction 6.5.5.
Jewishness suggested based on vicinity to other Jewish tombs, but see Introduction 6.5.5.
This form is not recorded elsewhere, but may derive from the same root.
Buried in the same tomb with Joshua (23), see Introduction 6.5.5.
See Introduction 2.1. For this orthography see Introduction 2.2.3.

Found in the cemetery at Gamarat, Carthage, see Introduction 6.5.4. The inscription is accompanied by a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1. It is written in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.2. On this being a name and not a blessing see Ilan, Silencing the Queen, 274.
For the ν see above, n. 15.
Found in the cemetery at Gamarat, Carthage, see Introduction 6.5.4. For this inscription’s Jewishness see Ilan, Silencing the Queen 274.
For the ν see above, n. 15.
For the נ see above, n. 15.
The Aramaic reads here בר, but this is clearly a female name. I assume the fall of the letter ת is a scribal error.
The amulet is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.2. This name is also predominantly Jewish, see above, n. 1.

Although the name שלום is mainly female at this time, and although the suffix ה is clearly feminine (see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.6, p. 23) and the Latin and Greek forms “Salona” are known for women, both amulets 7a and 7b (found together) record the male form בר (son) for this person.
For this sort of abbreviation see Introduction 2.3.1.
Jewishness indicated by name, see Introduction 6.6.
On this form see under Sarah (B/F) in vol. 1, n. 5, p. 255.
The inscription is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.2.
This name, in this form, was popular in Egypt and Cyrenaica, see above, n. 1.
Her (nameless) son is described in the papyrus as [̓Ιο]υδαίου (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.4.
So is this name recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 138, and Introduction 2.2.1.
Jewishness suggested based on name, but see above, n. 1.
Her freedman paid the Jewish tax, see Introduction 6.1.5.1. In this case her name adds to the likeliness that she was Jewish, despite above, n. 1.
For this sort of abbreviation see Introduction 2.3.1.
Jewishness indicated by name of son, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
The reading is according to Clarysse, “Jews in Trikomia,” 195. The edition princeps had ̔Ωρᾶς, and see above, n. 4.
See above, n. 8. This reading may well be incorrect, see previous note.

The papyrus is both very Jewish in character (including expressions such as ̓Αδωναὶ ̓Ελο[αὶ Σα ]βαώθ = אדוני אלהי צבאות, and Jewish angel names, but see Introduction 6.2.5) and the mother’s name – Sarah, but see Introduction 6.6.4.1. Both components probably justify the assumption that the customer of this amulet was Jewish, but do not decide it.
The document is composed in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.4.
The papyrus is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
The declension is probably a scribal error, see Introduction 2.8.5.
Found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3.
The inscription is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.2.
See above n. 4. In Rome, it is unlikely that a name other than the biblical Sarah was intended. On the single consonant see Introduction 2.3.3.4.
See above, n. 26. The inscription is accompanied by a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1.
So is this name recorded in the Vulgate, see Introduction 2.2.2.
Jewishness of inscription indicated by a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1, and by the Hebrew word – בשלום (in peace), see Introduction 6.2.2.

state.note: Veturia (1) Paucla (1), mother of the synagogue of the Campesians and Volumnians, aged 86

person.note: See above, n. 32. On the single consonant see Introduction 2.4.3. This time it is in Latin.
In Latin – Mater synagogarum Campi et Bolumni … quae bixit an LXXXVI meses VI (=86 years and 6 months).

Jewishness of inscription indicated by a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1, and by the title “mater synagogarum” (mother of the synagogue), see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.2. The woman is described in the inscription as a “proselita” (=proselyte), see Introduction 6.1.6.2.
For this second name see Williams, JSJ 38 (2007) 322.
Jewishness indicated by a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1.
See above, n. 26. It is accompanied by the Hebrew words – שלום על משכהבו (peace on her resting-place), see Introduction 6.2.2.

state.note: Opilio (1) and Catella (1)’s daughter, Hintius (1)’s wife, aged 70

person.note: In Latin – que vixit annus p(lus) m(inus) LXX.
See above, n. 26. It is accompanied by the Hebrew formula – שלום על משכבהו (peace on her resting-place), see Introduction 6.2.2.

Jewishness suggested based on name, but see above, n. 1. Robert associated this inscription with another stone from the vicinity bearing Jewish symbols, see Lifshitz, in CIJ op. cit., but see Introduction 6.10.1.2.
Jewish indicated by Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.
The letters need to be those of a name, either this one, or they may be incomplete for שריה.

Described in the inscription as προσήλυτος (proselyte), see Introduction 6.1.6.2. Jewishness of tomb indicated by the name Joseph (105) found therein, see 6.5.5. The name Sarah was not necessarily given to her after conversion, see Introduction 6.6.4.1.
These dates are found on inscriptions in this tomb.
So the date of this tomb is calculated by the editor.
Jewishness suggested based on name, but see above, n. 1.
Buried in the same cave as Joshua (22), see Introduction 6.5.5.
See above, n. 7. The ο is probably a scribal error, see Introduction 2.8.4.
The name was found on a Jewish ossuary from Jerusalem, see Introduction 6.5.6.

This burial cave was identified as housing Jews from Cyrenaica, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.3.1.1, p. 49. This person is recorded under Sarah (4) (B/F) in vol. 1, p. 255, but not included in the statistics.
The name was found on a Jewish ossuary from Jerusalem, see Introduction 6.5.6.

This burial cave was identified as housing Jews from Cyrenaica, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.3.1.1, p. 49. This person is recorded under Sarah (5) (B/F) in vol. 1, p. 255, but not included in the statistics.
In Greek – Κυρίνου. The editors thought this was a personal name, but the wide dispersion of the name Sarah in this orthography in Cyrenaica suggests that it may be a place-name here too.
The inscription was found in a Jewish cemetery, in Palestine, see Introduction 6.5.7.
This is the year in which Beth She’arim was destroyed, probably in the Gallus Uprising.

Jewishness suggested based on name, however, see above, n. 1. The editor wrote: “Sara e Sarra sono nomi di donna ben noti nell’epigrafia ebraica.” He thought the stone may come from a Jewish catacomb in Rome.
See above, n. 8. The editor too saw the problem for he wrote: “The name Sarra may be Germanic, if it is the counterpart of Sarus,” Kotansky, PC 22/1 (1994) 40.
On the interchange of θ and τ see introduction 2.3.3.6. On the double consonant see Introduction 2.3.3.4. The declension is probably a scribal error, see Introduction 2.8.5.
Jewishness suggested based on name, but it is not recorded elsewhere as a Hebrew name in Egypt, and her father’s name is Egyptian.
So is this name recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 70, and Introduction 2.2.1.
The inscription is accompanied by a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1.

div.note: Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 25:3. אביגיל was the name of one of King David’s wives.
Biblical, Ex 6:23. אלישבע was Aaron’s wife.

Biblical, e.g. Esth 2:7. אסתר was the queen who gave her name to the biblical book. It resembles closely the name ̓Αστερία in Greek (WGE, 162) and the name Astrius in Latin (RNGCL 24). Thus, it is not at all clear if all the finds of this name can always be viewed as indicating Jewishness. In this corpus, unless other criteria are appended, the mere use of the form of this name is not considered Jewish.

ברכה means “blessing” in Hebrew, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 195. The name ברכה is recorded for a male in the Bible, see 1 Chr 12:3. On the interchange between male and female names see vol. 1, Introduction 1.5.2, p. 15.
Biblical, e.g. Judg 4:4. דבורה was a prophetess and judge.

Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 1:2. חנה was the prophet Samuel’s mother. The transliteration of this name into Greek and Latin is reminiscent of a Latin female name Annia (from Annius). Therefore, in and of itself, in this corpus this name is no indication of Jewishness.

Biblical, Gen 26:34. יהודית was Esau’s wife. The name is derived from the male יהודה, see Introduction 1.1.2.1.The most famous Judith of Second Temple times is ̓Ιουδείθ of the apocryphal book by that name.
יוחנה is the feminine form of the biblical יוחנן (e.g. Jer 40:16). It is, however, never mentioned in the Bible. It was probably invented in post-biblical times, see Introduction 1.1.2.1.

Biblical, e.g. Jon 1:1. יונה was the name of the prophet who gave his name to a biblical book. In the Bible the name is male, but because of the meaning of the name (=dove) it quickly became a female name as well, and has remained bi-sexual to this day, see Introduction 1.1.2.1.
Biblical, e.g. Judg 4:17. יעל is the Kenite woman who slew Sisra.
יצחקוס is the feminine form of the biblical יצחק (e.g. Gen 17:19). It is, however, never mentioned in the Bible. It was probably invented in post-biblical times, see Introduction 1.1.2.1.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 29:16. לאה was Jacob’s first wife.
Biblical, e.g. Ex 15:20. מרים was Moses’ sister.
Biblical, e.g. Ruth 1:2. נעמי was Ruth’s mother-in-law.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 22:23. רבקה was Isaac’s wife.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 29:6. רחל was Jacob’s beloved wife.

שבתית is the feminine form of the biblical שבתאי (e.g. Ezra 10:15). It is, however, never mentioned in the Bible. It was probably invented in post-biblical times, see Introduction 1.1.2.1. In vol. 1, I mistakenly listed it under Greek female names (p. 323). The name and its many derivatives became very popular in the Diaspora, because of its association with the Jewish Shabbat, but soon lost its unique Jewish character and, particularly in Egypt, became a common pagan and then Christian name, see CPJ vol. 3, 43-56, and Cohen, “Shabtai.” It is an unlikely indication of Jewishness despite assertions of many scholars, see Introduction 6.6.6.

In the Bible שלום is recorded only as a man’s name (one of the last kings of Israel, e.g. 2 Kgs 15:10). The name שלום-Σαλώμη was the second most popular woman’s name in Palestine during Second Temple times, see vol. 1, Introduction 1.1.2.1, pp. 9 and 249-53. It was certainly a woman’s (rather than a man’s) name and when found on ossuaries in the Hebrew form, שלום, denotes a name rather than a blessing (unlike in later inscriptions from Palestine and in contemporary Jewish inscriptions abroad – CIJ nos. 283, 293, 319, 597, 671 etc., see Ilan, Silencing the Queen 261-75). It is an independent name and not a short form of שלמציון (see Ilan, SCI 11 [1991-2] 155-7).
שמואליס is the feminine form of the biblical שמואל (e.g. 1 Sam 1:20). It is, however, never mentioned in the Bible. It was probably invented in post-biblical times, see Introduction 1.1.2.1.

Biblical, e.g. Gen. 17:15. שרה was Abraham’s wife. The name Saras was particularly popular in Cyrenaica, though it was probably not Jewish, but rather an abbreviation of Sarapia (see under Sarapia [G/F]). When used by scholars as a criterion for identifying the Jewishness of a person in Egypt (9 in this corpus) and Cyrenaica (11 in this corpus), with no other strict criteria, his/her Jewishness is doubted, and see Introduction 6.6.4.1.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 38:6. תמר was Judah’s daughter-in-law and mother of his children.
